 The known solution in C++ that we found ( which passed in a contest) is:

   for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        long long last = 0;
        long long cnt = 0;
        for (int j = i+1; j < n; j++) {
            long long k = last / a[j] + 1;
            cnt += k;
            last = k * a[j];
        }
        last = 0;
        for (int j = i-1; j >=0; j--) {
            long long k = last / a[j] + 1;
            cnt += k;
            last = k * a[j];
        }
        ans = min(ans, cnt);
   }

 In this solution, the left part is processed from i-1 downto 0, not by reversing the array and then processing normally, but by processing in reverse order of indices.

 In our function f(l) in program2.py, if we are passed the left part in reversed order ( which is from i-1 downto to 0, but then as a list, it is [a_{i-1}, a_{i-2}, ... , a0] ) and then we process in the given order, then it is the same as the known solution.
